I'm [AGENT NAME]. Share your name and preferred pronouns. And share something about yourself, such as your program of study or a hobby you have.|We will start in a couple of minutes.

You will need paper and a pen or pencil (or a good drawing program on your computer) to practice drawing ray diagrams in this activity. A ruler or straight edge will also be helpful. If you have these materials but need to fetch them, please do so now.

You will find images and instructions for this activity in the "Activity Plan" tab to the left. If you prefer, you can download a copy of the plan at https://erebor.lti.cs.cmu.edu/images/Physics_Module1_Activity_Plan.pdf

Examine the image of a swimming pool in the Activity Plan tab. It shows a “1 FEET DEEP” sign on the side of a children’s pool. Discuss the following questions:|Why do some of the letters in “FEET DEEP” look different even though they are all painted the same size?|Why do you see multiple letters, even though each word is painted once?|Take five minutes to discuss possible explanations.

Now based on your discussion, use ray diagrams to account for all the effects in this image. Take up to five minutes for each of you to draw your own ray diagrams on paper or using a drawing program on your computer. I encourage you to use a ruler or straight edge. If feasible, if you can create a public URL for your image, you may share your images for discussion by pasting the URL for your images into the Sharing Space tab at the left.
I will now share one of my ray diagrams with you in the Sharing Space tab at the left.
Which feature or part of the image does this diagram correspond to, and how does it account for this feature? What does the black vertical arrow represent?|Discuss for up to 3 minutes.

Compare this diagram to your diagram(s). Resolve any discrepancies. Why does my ray diagram include multiple rays coming from the top and the bottom of each “letter”? Take a couple of minutes to compare and discuss.
I will share another ray diagram in the Sharing Space. Take up to 4 minutes to discuss my diagram and to compare and contrast my diagram to yours.
What feature of the image does this diagram correspond to? How does this diagram help explain that feature of the image? What ideas did I need to apply to draw this diagram?
I will now share my last ray diagram with you in the Sharing Space. Take up to 4 minutes to discuss my diagram and to compare and contrast my diagram to yours.
What feature or part of the image does it correspond to, and how does it account for this feature? What ideas did I need to apply to draw this diagram?
Take two minutes to reflect. What, if anything, did you learn about optics or ray diagrams from this activity? We will move on to the second activity soon.
We will now move on to Activity 2 in the Activity Plan. You may need to scroll down to see Activity 2 on the second page. Examine the figures at the beginning of the activity.

Your task is to determine which side of the foil (the flat or prism side) was facing the flashlight in experiment (a) and which in experiment (b). Use ray diagrams and calculations to justify your answer.|If feasible, if you can create a public URL for your image, you may share your image by pasting the URL for your images into the Sharing Space for discussion.|Remember it will help your learning if you can each draw your own diagram, even if you cannot share it now.
Check that you agree on the incident angles from air into the foil, and from the foil back into the air, for case (a) and case (b).
Do you agree on the refracted angles at each surface in case (a)?
I will now share one of my diagrams with you in the Sharing Space.
Did you draw a similar diagram? Which case, (a) or (b), does this diagram correspond to? Does this diagram support your argument?|Take 2-3 minutes to discuss.
I will share my diagram with you for the other case in the Sharing Space.
Is this diagram consistent with your diagram(s)? Take up to two minutes to discuss.

We will move on now to the last question. How will the performance of the foil change if you cover the prism side of the foil with a layer of water (thick enough to fill and flatten the grooves)? Take five minutes to discuss.
If you don’t remember the index of refraction of water, remember you can look it up online.
Can you use ray diagrams to support your arguments?
Ok, now I will share my ray diagrams with you in the Sharing Space.
Do my ray diagrams agree with yours? Do they support your arguments?|Discuss for 2-3 minutes and describe any discrepancies.
We will wrap up soon. Take two minutes to reflect. What, if anything, did you learn from this activity?

It is time for us to wrap up now. It has been a pleasure working with you. The activity is now over.|Note you may save your discussion for future studying using the “Download Discussion Log” button. If you ran out of time for any part of the activity, you may work on it independently or with your study group at another time. Please post any questions you have on Piazza.|Have a nice day!
